fact: The first computer virus was created in 1983 and was called the Elk Cloner.
The term 'bug' in computer programming originated from a real insect that caused a malfunction in a computer.
The QWERTY keyboard layout, which is widely used today, was designed in the 1870s for typewriters.
The first domain name ever registered was symbolics.com on March 15, 1985.
The World Wide Web was invented by Sir Tim Berners-Lee in 1989.
The average computer mouse is moved approximately 27 feet per day.
The first hard disk drive, introduced in 1956, could only store 5 megabytes of data.
The first computer programmer was Ada Lovelace, who wrote the first algorithm for Charles Babbage's Analytical Engine in the 1840s.
The acronym 'URL' stands for Uniform Resource Locator.
The first electronic computer, ENIAC, weighed more than 27 tons and occupied about 1,800 square feet of floor space.
The CAPTCHA system was developed to distinguish humans from bots by asking them to complete tasks that are easy for humans but difficult for machines.
The concept of cloud computing dates back to the 1960s with the idea of an 'intergalactic computer network' proposed by J.C.R. Licklider.
The first computer mouse was made of wood.
The first computer virus to receive significant media attention was the Morris Worm, which spread across the internet in 1988.
The programming language Python is named after the British comedy group Monty Python.
The first smartphone, called Simon Personal Communicator, was introduced by IBM in 1992.
The concept of a computer 'virus' was first introduced by computer scientist Fred Cohen in the 1980s.
The term 'Wi-Fi' does not stand for anything. It is a trademarked term intended to be a play on the word 'hi-fi' (high fidelity).
The concept of open-source software promotes collaboration and sharing of code, allowing anyone to view, modify, and distribute the software's source code.
The first known computer programmer was a woman named Ada Lovelace, who worked on Charles Babbage's Analytical Engine in the mid-1800s.
